title: [$250] Fix race conditions and redundant writes in OnyxDerived initialisation

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Daily
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: Help Wanted
labels.description: Apply this label when an issue is open to proposals by contributors

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

body:
Coming from proposal [here](https://expensify.slack.com/archives/C05LX9D6E07/p1771853495488139) ### Background: On app startup, OnyxDerived/index.ts initialises derived Onyx values — computed values that depend on multiple Onyx stores. For each derived key, it attempts to restore a cached value from disk, falls back to an eager computation via tupleGet, and sets up connectWithoutView listeners (one per dependency) to recompute whenever dependencies change. Derived configs like reportAttributes use the areAllConnectionsSet context flag to decide whether to run a full computation or return an empty default. ### Problem: The initialisation flow has three race conditions and correctness issues: 1.  tupleGet overwrites fresher connection data: tupleGet is a Promise that resolves asynchronously. Meanwhile, connectWithoutView callbacks can fire before tupleGet resolves, writing fresher data to dependencyValues via setDependencyValue. When tupleGet finally resolves, it replaces the entire dependencyValues array reference (dependencyValues = values), discarding any fresher values that connection callbacks already wrote. Those values won't be restored until the dependency changes again. 2. tupleGet computes with uninitialised data: The tupleGet callback calls compute(dependencyValues, ...) before assigning dependencyValues = values, so the initial computation always runs on an array of undefined values. Additionally, it passes areAllConnectionsSet: false in the context, causing compute functions like reportAttributes to short-circuit and return empty defaults ({reports: {}, locale: null}), making the entire tupleGet path produce useless output. 3. Disk-cached value immediately overwritten: When a derived value IS restored from disk, the code proceeds to set up connection listeners. Each listener triggers recomputeDerivedValue → compute → Onyx.set. Since areAllConnectionsSet is false until all N connections fire, compute functions return empty defaults. This immediately overwrites the valid disk-cached value with {reports: {}, locale: null}, causing a flash of empty data. This produces N-1 unnecessary Onyx.set calls per derived key during initialisation — all writing empty defaults. ### Solution: 1. Remove tupleGet entirely: Since connection callbacks already populate dependencyValues incrementally and recomputeDerivedValue can defer until all connections are ready, tupleGet is redundant. The first full computation happens naturally when the last connection fires. 2. Defer Onyx.set until all connections are established: Add an early return in recomputeDerivedValue when areAllConnectionsSet is false. Dependency values still accumulate correctly via setDependencyValue, but no compute or Onyx write occurs until the last connection initialises. This prevents overwriting disk-cached values with empty defaults and eliminates N-1 wasted writes. Performance Gains: - Cold Start -> 14.7s - 13.3s (-9.5%) - Warm Start -> 1.5s - 1.3s (-13.3%)
Issue OwnerCurrent Issue Owner: @shubham1206agra

  • Upwork Job ID: 2026567465536380599

title: npm run prettier behaves inconsistently between local and CI

labels.name: Reviewing
labels.description: Has a PR in review

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Daily
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

labels.name: Melvin Triage
labels.description: Automatic AI Analysis of an issue

body:
## Problem

Running `npm run prettier` locally reports success and doesn't make or report any changes, but CI fails with "Prettier diff detected" on the same file. The local and CI prettier behavior is inconsistent.

This could be caused by different prettier/node versions, different config being picked up, or something in `scripts/runPrettier.sh` behaving differently between environments.

Example workflow failure: https://github.com/Expensify/App/actions/runs/22363352177/job/64722629957

## Solution

Investigate why prettier behaves differently locally vs CI. Ensure `npm run prettier` produces the same results in both environments.

**Workaround**: Run `npx prettier --write <file>` directly on the affected file instead of using `npm run prettier`.

cc @Expensify/mobile-deployers

The test passes locally. ## Solution Determine the root cause and fix it.
